forecast.no_outcome_scenario: All MLB players have batting averages below .400 on June 1, 2025. Any players who were on a hot streak in April and May experience a natural regression toward their career norms as the sample size of at-bats increases, causing their averages to dip and remain below the .400 mark.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: An elite, high-contact hitter has an exceptionally hot start to the 2025 season. By mid-May, their average is already in the high .300s (e.g., .380+), and they continue their streak for the final two weeks of the month, keeping their average at or above .400 through the June 1st deadline.
forecast.rationale:
My forecast is based on the historical rarity of this event. Hitting .400 is exceedingly difficult, even for a two-month stretch. The last player to have a batting average of .400 or higher on June 1st appears to be Chipper Jones in 2008 (.409). This indicates a base rate of roughly once every 15-20 years, suggesting a low probability. The modern baseball environment, with its high-velocity pitchers and specialized relievers, makes sustained high batting averages challenging for all hitters. The status quo is that this event does not happen in a typical season.

My probability is not lower than 15% because the event is not impossible, and the conditions for it to occur are plausible. It only requires one player out of roughly 50-60 qualified hitters to maintain a hot streak. The June 1st date is key; the sample size of at-bats (roughly 170-190) is still small enough to allow for such an outlier performance. Additionally, recent rule changes restricting defensive shifts could provide a slight tailwind for high-contact hitters, marginally increasing the chance of a .400 run.

My probability is not higher than 15% because the historical data is a powerful counterargument. Despite the theoretical possibility, it has proven to be a very infrequent occurrence in the 21st century. To forecast a higher probability would be to overweight the chance of an outlier and underweight the strong evidence of historical precedent and the general difficulty of hitting in the modern era.

I would update my forecast upwards significantly if, on May 19, 2025, there is a qualified hitter with a batting average already above .385. Conversely, I would update downwards if the league leader in batting average is below .350 on that date.
